2.caption: With Postgres, the primary index and secondary indexes all point directly to the on-disk tuple offsets. When a tuple location changes, all indexes must be updated.

3.caption: MySQL uses an extra layer of indirection: secondary index records point to primary index records, and the primary index itself holds the on-disk row locations. If a row offset changes, only the primary index needs to be updated.
